REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 5 Report of the State Auditor State of Nebraska AUDITOR'S OFFICE Lincoln To Hon. Keith Neville, Governor of Nebraska. My Dear Sir: In accordance with the laws of this state relating to the department of the State Auditor, I am submitting herewith my report for the biennial period from November 30, 1916, to December 1, 1918. . You will find here- with tabulated statements showing in detail the receipts and expenditures during that period, as well as the condition of the various funds appro- priated by the Thirty-fifth Session of the State Legislature. These appropriations were made on a peace-time basis, but the great world-war has increased the cost of all supplies purchased by the state to the extent that it has been a serious drain upon the appropriations, and the result is that some of them are very low. Less care than has been exercised in the management of the affairs of the state would have resulted in many of them being exhausted entirely. The following summarized statement will show the receipts from all sources and the payments made for all purposes during the two-year period embraced in the last biennium: Permanent School Fund Nebraska's permanent school fund now contains $10,574,527.85, which is invested in bonds issued mainly by the various subdivisions of the state, a list of which will be found in statement No. 18. The state now derives from this investment approximately a million dollars a year. This fund is distributed to the various schools of the state, and represents a portion of the payments made during the past biennium. Bond Registration The war has" had the effect of diminishing the number of bond issues submitted to this department for approval and registration, although the aggregate amount of the issues is greater than during' the pre - vious biennium. During the past biennium we have registered a total ialance on hand November 30, 1916 $1,288,674.39 Leceipts during the biennium 15,026,919.41 'ayments during the biennium $16,315,593.81 15,446,849.61 Balance November 30, 1918 ...» 1,392,019.4 1,392,019.4!

6 REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS of 455 issues aggregating $7,651,488.10, as compared to 581 issues during the previous biennium aggregating $7,056,639.08. The greatest de - crease has been in the issuance of school bonds, only seventy-one of these having been registered the past two years, as compared to 203 during the previous biennium. But the seventy-one issues aggregated $2,319,897.00 as compared to an aggregate of $2,414,100.00 for the 203 issues. This would indicate that many small districts have suspended improvements because of the war. In this connection I would suggest that it is my opinion, after four years of observation, that bonds issued by Nebraska's sub-divisions should be exempt from taxation that the investment of home funds therein might be stimulated. Other than those purchased by the state as an investment for the school funds, a vast majority of those issued are sold outside the state. Bonds invariably draw a low rate of interest — before the war it was between four and five per cent — and when taxed it made the rate so low that they were an unprofitable investment for Nebraska people. The result has been that in 1916 only $131,598 were listed for taxation, in 1917 $168,830, and in 1918 $149,002. Of course a lot of bonds were not listed for taxation that should have been listed, but as a whole the state would be losing practically nothing in taxes by exempting them, while on the other hand it would have the effect of stimulating the investment of home funds in them. The war has edu - cated the public to the investment in bonds, and the more the people are encouraged to invest in legitimate propositions the less they will be disposed to invest in wild cat concerns that promise big dividends — and possibly pay them as long as they are able to sell stock — but in which the prospects for recovering any great part of the original invest - ment are very poor. County Treasurer Examinations. Three examinations of the offices of the various county treasurers of the state have been made the past biennium, while in some cases four examinations have been conducted. During the term of my immediate predecessor an examination was made of nearly all the offices once in a year, while prior to that time the state was covered on an average of once in each twenty-two months, and an additional examiner was asked for that the state might be covered once a year. We therefore feel considerable pride and satisfaction in the accomplishments of our de - partment. Special Legislative Salaries and Expenses. The special session of the legislature held in the early part of the present year made an appropriation to pay the salary and mileage of the members. The claims of the senate members for salaries were presented, but rejected by this department, as we did not feel justified in issuing warrants without an interpretation of the law by the courts to determine whether or not they are entitled to pay during an extra session.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 7 In the matter of the mileage claims, however, we felt justified in issuing warrants in payment of them, as it seems to me there is as much justification in the payment of these claims as there is in the payment of the claims for traveling expenses of the district judges. Upon presentation of these warrants to the state treasurer for his signature, however, he with-held the same and the warrants were re - turned to this department, where they are being held subject to future action. The vouchers for the salary and mileage of the house members were drawn, and brought to this department by the chief clerk, but were retained by him when he ascertained the attitude towards the senate vouchers. County Treasurer Remittances. The state the past four years has been requiring monthly remit - tances of state funds from county treasurers. This resulted in a legal controversy with the treasurer of one of the counties, in which it was held that while the county treasurers must remit at such times as the state may require, yet unless a complete settlement is made with each treasurer and the state auditor upon blanks to be furnished by the latter, no penalty could be imposed, and with the penalty eliminated the state is back where it was four years ago, unless the treasurers are disposed to comply voluntarily with the request of the state. To make a complete settlement with each county treasurer once a month would make twelve times the amount of work for both the treasurer and this department that there is at present, and twelve bookkeepers would be required to do the work that is now performed by one. I would suggest, therefore, that a simple change be made in the law requiring the treasurers to remit at such times as may be required, and that final settlements be made only at the close of each year. The penalty should be retained to insure that the state's orders be carried out. Erroneous Remittances The county treasurer of Cheyenne county some time ago remitted to the state treasurer the sum of $368.37. This was intended for the school land lease fund, but by mistake was sent to the school land prin - cipal fund. As a result the latter fund is long to the amount stated, while the lease fund is short. A similar error was made on the part of the treasurer of Box Butte county, wherein the amount involved was $610.00. A collection of $350.00 in the latter county has since been used as an off-set. In the Box Butte county case the treasurer has filed for presenta - tion to the legislature with this department a claim for $610.00. This could be allowed in the sum of $260.00 and it would simply be used to correct the error, I believe, however, the simplest way to handle the problem, would be to authorize the state treasurer to make the neces - sary transfer on his books.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 8 In Conclusion There is an attraction to a public position that is alluring to most of those who aspire to them, but after four years of service in my present position, as well as some time devoted to minor places, I sub - mit the question — is it worth the effort ? ■ I assume that my services to the state have been reasonably satis - factory. My administration has been free from the criticism that is 80 often directed at those who serve the public, and I enjoy the many friendships that have been formed. I have enjoyed the work on the various boards wherein the affairs of the state are in the main directed. I have enjoyed the intimate acquaintance of the various state officers and employes with whom I have come in contact. I have enjoyed the daily visits of the "press gang" — of John M. Thompson of the State Journal, who for nearly twenty-eight years has kept tab on the public's affairs at the state house; of E. E. Wolfe of the Lincoln Daily Star, from whose observation but little in the way of news, is permitted to escape; of Pell Barrows of the Omaha Bee, who will become the lieutenant governor of the state on the day my associates and I retire, and of Earl B. Gaddis, of the Omaha World-Herald, prior to his transfer to Washington. My own office force has been a source of satisfaction because of its co-operation in the effort to make the administration of the affairs of the department a success. In particular I would commend Mr. Fred C. Ayres, who, during almost the entire period, has been the efficient deputy, and of Mr. G. W. Ellsworth, who has served as the bond-clerk and recorder. Then there is John J. Mahoney, who has served as a county treasurer examiner during my entire term, and L. R. Willis, who has also been with the department from the first. These friendships and associations, as well as the acquaintances formed during the period, and the conscientious belief that one has rendered the public fair and impartial service, are in the end one's chief reward for serving the public. Respectfully submitted, WM. H. SMITH, State Auditor. State House Lincoln, Nebraska, December 2, 1918.
PART I Statistical Report of the State Auditor
